dialogue.content: YOU are in Principal Foster's office. The Principal makes his announcements over the PA system.
Behind the Principal's shoulder is an oversized bay window. You look through the window, watching as rain pours down in sheets. There is a layer of fog draped over the school.
The Principal is lanky and rather caustic. He speaks with a forced English accent.

PRINCIPAL: Congratulations to our Senior Class, I hope you are having a great last day of finals week. I encourage you all to make good decisions as this momentous year comes to a close.
The Principal clicks off the PA system. His faux upbeat attitude fades away. He turns toward you, and clears his throat.

PRINCIPAL: As YOU well know, this past week, we at Jefferson High school took our finals. Ms. Grables calculus final for the junior class is one of the hardest in this school. 
It is a benchmark to which our faculty, and collegiate institutions measure student work. Thankfully...every single student in her class received an A on their exam...including you. You must be very proud of your work.

The Principal's office is decorated like a wannabee French artist's New York apartment. You spot a fake Van gogh painting on the wall behind you. 
PRINCIPAL: Am I not holding your attention? 
You shake your head.
The Principal clears his throat.

YOU: What does it matter? 
PRINCIPAL: I'm concerned...You expect me to believe that both you and your peers attained their scores by miraculously finding some newfound focus and determination?

YOU: I am... Worked my ass off. Glad I got an A.
PRINCIPAL: ...You expect me to believe that both you and your peers attained their scores by miraculously finding some newfound focus and determination?

PRINCIPAL: That's impossible. Some of these "A students" averaged a 2.8 GPA throughout the semester. After four straight C's trying to guess what Pi is on a pop quiz, these students manage to ace Jefferson's hardest test?...I've formed a hypothesis...

PRINCIPAL: Some of these "A students" averaged a 2.8 GPA throughout the semester. After four straight C's trying to guess what Pi is on a pop quiz, these students manage to ace Jefferson's hardest test?... I've formed a hypothesis...

PRINCIPAL: It seems impossible. Some of these "A students" averaged a 2.8 GPA throughout the semester. After four straight C's trying to guess what Pi is on a pop quiz, these students manage to ace Jefferson's hardest test?...I've formed a hypothesis...
PRINCIPAL: I believe that YOU and your classmates cheated on the exam. The Calculus answer keys went missing two days before the exam. I'm sure you know what I am talking about.
PRINCIPAL: Bingo! Nailed it! The most puzzling piece to this whole predicament is that the Calculus answer keys went missing two days before the exam. I'm sure you know what I am talking about.

YOU: That does not concern me. 
PRINCIPAL: But it does! There is a puzzling piece to this whole predicament. The Calculus answer keys went missing two days before the exam. I'm sure you know what I am talking about.

YOU: Wait, hold on for one second... Are you suggesting that it was me? I'm trying to go to college next year. I would not steal any tests...Absolutely not... 
PRINCIPAL: College is a seriously bold idea you have there, especially considering your record. You were expelled from your previous school...brought fireworks on a school bus? Reputation carries weight. At this school, we do not tolerate academic dishonesty. You are expelled. Go clean out your locker.

YOU: Am I not awarded a fair hearing? 
PRINCIPAL: You will not be returning to Jefferson for senior year. 
YOU: I didn't do anything!
The Principal holds his hand up, motioning for you to exit. There is nothing left to say.

YOU exit the Principal's office in complete shock, and obvious confusion.
Why YOU? It can't just be your past. This doesn't make sense, you did not steal the tests.

You open the door to Principal Foster's office.
You: I didn't steal them! I want to speak with the board director. 
PRINCIPAL: This does not help your case. Get out of my office quickly. You have no right to speak with the director.
The hallway is empty, save for two Ms. Grables class's students engaged in a public make-out session about ten feet away. Everyone else must still be at lunch. You've never liked this place.

YOU exit the Principal's office in desperation. You did not do this. You promised your parents you would get better, and you have. Your family cannot support private school. This is the end of your schooling career.
You arrive at your messy locker and open up your black Jansport.

You walk over to the oblivious couple, they continue to make out. 
YOU: You're in Ms. Grables class right?
The couple continues to make out...

YOU: HEY!
The couple stop, they are taken aback.
BOYF: You're kind of interrupting us here.
YOU: You were in Grables class with me.
BOY: Yeah?
YOU: Do you know where I can find the answer keys?
BOY: Grables keeps them in her room...in the desk. 
YOU: Thanks.
GIRL: Can you fuck off please?

You leave.
You arrive at your messy locker and open up your black Jansport.
Your locker is exceedingly messy. Papers and tests are strewn everywhere. A flyer is taped hastily on the inside of the door. There are two kit-kat wrappers stuck to the bottom of your locker.

You start to collect the mess of papers. There is a B+ essay on The Odyssey for English. Just under the essay is a B- biology test. You hold these two assignments in your hands. 
YOU: I did the math. I got an A- on that biology test...teacher hates me. 
You spot one more paper on the floor of your locker, the review sheet for Ms. Grables Calculus test. You stop sorting through the papers. You open up your Jansport and fill it with the messy contents of the locker. Fuck this school.

You examine a flyer on your locker wall:

ANGER MANAGEMENT W/ MS. SAMUELS - 3:30 PM
	"Get your head together!"

You stop examining the flyer.
YOU: These classes have been surprisingly helpful. Guess that's done.
You open up your Jansport and fill it with the messy contents of the locker. Fuck this school.

You grab your bag and start to head towards the exit. You can't help but stop. 
YOU: He said Ms. Grables class... 
You check your surroundings. Just to your left, in the hallway, is Ms. Grables classroom. You walk to her door, just before entering, you pause for a moment. Should you? What do you hope to find?...What do you have to lose?

The door to Ms. Grables classroom slowly creaks open. 
YOU: Hello, anyone here?  
All the lights are off. The smell of Ms. Grables perfume hangs in the air. You never knew that something could smell fruity and musky.

You approach the window and look out towards the back fence of Jefferson. The fog has only encroached further into town, the huffing wind rising up to rustle the broad window. Tiny rain droplets multiply against the glass. The day is not even into the afternoon, yet the predominantly dark clouds are menacing. The sky is grey velvet. 
YOU: This town fuckin' sucks.
All the lights are off. The smell of Ms. Grables perfume hangs in the air. You never knew that something could smell fruity and musky.

You head to the neat rows of organized wooden desks. You move towards the back of the classroom, and spot a desk with carved lettering in its wood. 
You examine the desk for something helpful...

Ms. Grables desk is not what you come to expect from a calculus teacher, it is exceedingly messy. 
Graded quizzes are strewn across her desk, alongside a half eaten box of donuts. Her computer is an old, dated public school desktop.
You need to input the password to get access to her computer.

The computer loads in, you've entered the correct password.
